Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story:
I glance at the clock on my monitor—ten minutes until my break. My headset crackles as another prospect picks up. “Hello, this is Alex from BrightNet. Can I tell you about our new service?” The man on the line immediately asks about upload speeds and data caps, questions my script only half-answers. I try to sound confident, but he’s persistent, and I’m supposed to handle every objection, keep him engaged, never admit uncertainty. My stomach knots. I’m also watching the time because today is voting day, and I promised myself I’d make my voice count.

When my break finally comes, I rush to the polling station, only to be told my registration doesn’t match. The official says I need to fill out a provisional ballot form, but the station closes in ten minutes. She’s firm: follow every instruction, no shortcuts, or my vote won’t count. I stare at the form, pen trembling, phone buzzing in my pocket—my supervisor expects me back on calls, handling objections, not missing a beat. But the official’s eyes are on me, waiting. I feel torn, the weight of two worlds pressing in, each demanding I do the right thing, right now.
